node.text: Climate change has been on everyone's minds lately. From the alarming occurrence of wildfires, floods and extreme weather events to the UN’s newest Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report, it’s easy to feel scared, angry or hopeless. Turns out, it's not just our communities and physical well-being that are being harmed by climate change — it's our mental heath too, according to science writer Britt Wray (@gen_dread). “We cannot afford to treat the psychological impacts of climate change as some afterthought,” says Wray. “Mental health needs to be an integral part of any climate change survival strategy.” To learn more about how a warming world affects us — and what we can do about it — watch her full talk: http://t.ted.com/Gj9DE7y

node.title: Talking About Climate Change Means Talking About Mental Health

node.text: Can a game of peekaboo really change the world? Yes! Because kids’ brains develop faster in their first 5 years of life than in any other period, what parents and caregivers do — or don't do — in those years matters. A lot. And interactive games like peekaboo can help build core skills like memory, trust, empathy and imagination. But don’t just take our word for it! In this TED Talk, created in partnership with @minderoofoundation, 7-year-old Molly Wright walks through the research-backed ways that you can support the babies, toddlers and young children in your life thrive by 5. To hear more from Molly about why playing peekaboo is a must for all kids, watch her adorable full talk here: http://t.ted.com/0YbX8vr

node.title: A Talk that All Parents Need to Hear

node.text: Being in a loving, committed partnership is not a guarantee for good sex, says relationship therapist Esther Perel (@estherperelofficial). In her TED Talk, she explains how the ways that you show love to a partner (reliability, security, protection) can sometimes be in direct conflict with the ingredients that spark desire (surprise, power, mischief). "Why is the forbidden so erotic?" she asks. "What is it about transgression that makes desire so potent?" Watch her full talk to learn the secrets of couples who manage to maintain a strong sexual connection: http://t.ted.com/bVejKYd

node.title: The Secret to Desire in Relationships

node.text: What is the real reason that athletes across many sports keep setting new records? Are humans simply getting taller, faster, stronger and just ... better? Or could there be another cause? In his TED Talk, David Epstein (@davidepstein) reveals that there are a number of factors behind the broken records. For one, "a form of artificial selection" has taken place within individual sports, drawing people with very specific body types. Here's an example: After the NBA signed an agreement in 1983 that made basketball a much more lucrative sport, the number of NBA players who were at least 7 feet tall doubled! Watch his fascinating full talk here: http://t.ted.com/kdKa26a

node.title: Are Humans Getting Faster and Stronger?

node.text: We need to call a time-out on "win-at-all-costs" culture and define what success really means, says Valorie Kondos Field, the former UCLA women's gymnastics coach. "As parents, as coaches, as leaders, we can no longer lead from a place where winning is our only metric of success, where our ego sits center stage," she explains in her TED Talk. "Real success is developing champions in life for our world — win or lose." Watch her brutally honest talk on the human consequences of our culture of winning here: http://t.ted.com/QCpwy7i

node.title: Why We Need to Redefine Success

node.text: Deep beneath the ocean's surface — 650 to 3,000 feet below! — lies a dark, frigid and rarely explored area called the “twilight zone”. It gets almost no sunlight and hovers around 40°F. 🥶 And the bottom dwellers that reside there? Just as otherworldly as the name of their home implies — they have bioluminescent bodies, tentacles galore, singular ways of moving and mating, and all kinds of other unique characteristics! But these critters are not just cool looking, they also play an important role in keeping CO2 out of our atmosphere. “The animals feed near the surface," says ocean scientist Heidi Sosik of Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute (@whoi.ocean). "They bring carbon in their food into the deep waters, where some of that carbon can stay behind and remain isolated from the atmosphere for hundreds or even thousands of years.” Watch her full talk on how she's leading the effort to protect and explore these uncharted waters and their inhabitants — and preserve their ability to protect the Earth’s climate: http://t.ted.com/rVrptCo

node.title: The Incredible Sea Creatures of the Twilight Zone

node.text: Do you struggle with feelings of shame? You’re not alone! So many of us experience shame in our everyday lives, according to vulnerability researcher and author @BreneBrown. "If you put shame in a petri dish, it needs three things to grow exponentially —secrecy, silence and judgment,” she explains. So how can you overcome these feelings? The key is empathy, says Brown. "If you put the same amount [of shame] in a petri dish and douse it with empathy, it can't survive." To learn about the amazing things that can happen when you confront your shame head on, watch Brené Brown’s full TED Talk here: http://t.ted.com/TSln3xB

node.title: We Need to Talk About Shame

node.text: Feeling stressed? In her TED Talk, Darria Long MD (@drdarria) shows how you can take back control even when your life starts to get "crazy busy". And she knows all about stress — she's an ER doctor! Her secret: Just like with patients in the hospital, you have to triage — or prioritize — the responsibilities that must be tackled first *and* then plan for the ones you know are coming. "Our brains all process stress in similar fundamental ways," she says. "But how we react to it has been shown by research to be modifiable, whether it's emergencies or just daily, day-in, day-out stress." To get more advice to help you juggle packed schedules and daily demands, watch her full talk here: http://t.ted.com/BBbZqZ7

node.title: Simple Ways to Reduce Stress Right Now

node.text: You may be hearing more about trans people these days — but contrary to what some may think, they've been around for a *long* time. Gender variance in humans is quite old, says actor and activist Samy Nour Younes. And knowing this history could make a big difference in public understanding and acceptance. He says, "Imagine how the conversation would shift if we acknowledge just how long trans people have been demanding equality." In his TED Talk, he shares the long and vibrant history of the #trans community — that we don't usually hear about. Watch the full talk here: http://t.ted.com/KTQ2mnA #Pride

node.title: The Long and Vibrant History of the Trans Community

node.text: Here are 2 pieces of life advice from actor @EthanHawke: 1) Find a way to express yourself; and 2) Don't worry if you're any good at it. In his TED Talk, he shares how he found an outlet for his creativity in acting and why creativity is for everyone. "Art's not a luxury; it's actually sustenance. We need it," he says. Watch his full talk on finding what you love and getting in touch with creativity: http://t.ted.com/i9IM0ay

node.title: The Secret to Discovering Your Creativity

node.text: Lawyer Bryan Stevenson (@itsbryan_stevenson) has dedicated his life to representing the marginalized and wrongly accused and fighting racial discrimination in the US justice system. As human beings, each person's survival is tied to everyone else's, he explains in his TED Talk. And we cannot evolve as a society until we deal with inequality. "Ultimately, you judge the character of a society, not by how they treat their rich and the powerful and the privileged," Stevenson explains, "but by how they treat the poor, the condemned, the incarcerated." Watch his full talk and see why he got the longest standing ovation in TED's history: http://t.ted.com/wwuN4Bw

node.title: We Need to Talk About an Injustice

node.text: Are double standards setting up girls to fail? Yes, says education activist and founder of Girls Who Code @ReshmaSaujani. In her TED Talk, she explains that while young boys are taught to be brave risk-takers, young girls are taught to be cautious perfectionists. These stereotypes stick with them even as they grow up and shape the lives they build for themselves. "I need each of you to tell every young woman you know to be comfortable with imperfection," declares Saujani. “We have to show them that they will be loved and accepted not for being perfect but for being courageous.“ For more on what it really takes to raise young women who will be confident *and* courageous, watch the full talk here: http://t.ted.com/HnFGaSu

node.title: We Must Raise Girls to Be Brave, Not Perfect

node.text: Climate change has been on everyone's minds lately. From the alarming occurrence of wildfires, floods and extreme weather events to the UN’s newest Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report, it’s easy to feel scared, angry or hopeless. Turns out, it's not just our communities and physical well-being that are being harmed by climate change — it's our mental heath too, according to science writer Britt Wray (@gen_dread). “We cannot afford to treat the psychological impacts of climate change as some afterthought,” says Wray. “Mental health needs to be an integral part of any climate change survival strategy.” To learn more about how a warming world affects us — and what we can do about it — watch her full talk: http://t.ted.com/Gj9DE7y

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on August 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TE TED MOTIVATION MONDAY "Creating isn't reserved for artists and entrepreneurs, it's the natural state in all ofus." ANDREW PEEK ENTREPRENEUR TED'.

node.text: Think you aren’t a creative person? Think again! Creating is all about letting go of the old — old habits, old identities, old ways of thinking — and that's something we all do, especially when we want to grow. In his TED Talk, entrepreneur Andrew Peek (@drupeek) argues that, in every moment, you are recreating yourself and you shouldn't be too attached to the same worn-out stories. "Are we wrapped in the warmth of the story we've been writing for decades?" he asks. "The further we are into a story, the less likely we are to want to rewrite it." Visit the link in our bio to watch his full talk on how letting go of your outdated narratives can help you create the life you want. #MondayMotivation

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on August 08, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text: What if we could design cities to be resilient to climate change — and even connect people back to the natural world? Landscape architect and @TEDFellow Kotchakorn Voraakhom (@kotch_voraakhom) has come up with an elegant solution: A multi-purpose, 11-acre green roof in the middle of busy Bangkok, Thailand, that responds to the region's flooding rains by holding over 3 million gallons of water and keeping it from overloading the sewage system and streets. On top of that, it's also Asia’s largest organic rooftop farm, providing fresh produce, jobs and green space for residents. Oh, and it also generates solar energy! Visit the link in our bio to learn more about this incredible space and how cities can design themselves to adapt to the climate:

node.text: Can a game of peekaboo really change the world? Yes! Because kids’ brains develop faster in their first 5 years of life than in any other period, what parents and caregivers do — or don't do — in those years matters. A lot. And interactive games like peekaboo can help build core skills like memory, trust, empathy and imagination. But don’t just take our word for it! In this TED Talk, created in partnership with @minderoofoundation, 7-year-old Molly Wright walks through the research-backed ways that you can support the babies, toddlers and young children in your life thrive by 5. To hear more from Molly about why playing peekaboo is a must for all kids, watch her adorable full talk here: http://t.ted.com/0YbX8vr

node.text:
Twerking is just a popular dance, right? Actually, it's a living piece of Black history! In her TED Talk, Grammy-nominated singer and songwriter @LizzoBeEating explains how the dances that inspired twerking were brought to the US by enslaved Africans through the trans-Atlantic slave trade. But as twerking has been appropriated and claimed by non-Black entertainers and performers, its rich cultural heritage has been ignored. “From TikTok trends to songs and humor, we see so much erasure of what Black people have created,” she explains. “Black people will not be erased from the creation, the history and the innovation of twerking.” Enjoyed this short clip from Lizzo’? Stay tuned for her full,  empowering, eye-opening talk — coming soon!

#lizzo #tedtalks #reels #twerk

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on August 02, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TED MOTIVATION MONDAY "Life is really just a lesson in finding the balance between fear and courage." CARA E. YAR KHAN ACTIVIST TED'.

node.text: Yes, it’s OK to be afraid sometimes. After being diagnosed with a rare genetic condition, human rights activist Cara E. Yar Khan (@cara_yarkhan) could have let her disability limit her. Instead, she took on a seemingly impossible task: A trek down the Grand Canyon ... that only 1% of visitors do! In her TED Talk, she describes how she learned to be brave — and how you can too. "Without fear, we'll do foolish things. And without courage, we'll never step into the unknown," she says. "The balance of the two is where the magic lies." Visit the link in our bio to watch her full talk — complete with heart-pounding footage from her trip. #MondayMotivation

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on August 01, 2021.

node.text: These katydids may not look like they're having sex, but they are. The male (right) is not only transferring a white blob of sperm to the female but also a nutritious green blob of food — what researchers call the "nuptial gift" — for her to eat. It takes a lot of effort for males to manufacture these gifts, which can weigh up to one-third of their body mass! "Sex in insects is more interesting than sex in people," declares evolutionary biologist Marlene Zuk. In her TED Talk, she describes the many sexual rules and roles of insects — and they are *way* different than ours — and how humans could learn a thing or two from them. To see more astonishing ways that insects get it on, visit the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on July 30, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says '3 Tips for Getting What You Need in the Bedroom FROM PSYCHOLOGIST GUY WINCH TED Tell your partner what you want 一 not what you don't want A positive request ("I'd love tif you would") will work much better than a criticism ("I don't like it when you"). Be as specific as possible Don't force your partner to fill in the blanks tell them exactly when, where and how. Make this a dialogue Give your partner the time to respond to your thoughts and share their own requests.'.

node.text: How open are you about your sexual desires? Even though it’s not easy, talking about them is crucial for a healthy relationship! So how do you tell your partner you're unhappy in the bedroom? According to psychologist @GuyWinch, most people just … don’t. "After working with hundreds of couples in my private practice," he writes, "what I’ve repeatedly seen is one partner believing they’ve clearly communicated their dissatisfaction to the other when, in fact, they did not." Here are 3 tips from Winch to help you be honest about what you need, without complaining or criticizing. Share this with your partner (and your friends!) and help encourage healthy conversations. Visit the link in our bio for more tips on how to have this tricky talk *and* get the results you want.

node.text: Being in a loving, committed partnership is not a guarantee for good sex, says relationship therapist Esther Perel (@estherperelofficial). In her TED Talk, she explains how the ways that you show love to a partner (reliability, security, protection) can sometimes be in direct conflict with the ingredients that spark desire (surprise, power, mischief). "Why is the forbidden so erotic?" she asks. "What is it about transgression that makes desire so potent?" Watch her full talk to learn the secrets of couples who manage to maintain a strong sexual connection: http://t.ted.com/bVejKYd

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on July 26, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'TED MOTIVATION MONDAY "Sometimes the unique perspective you have can result in unconventional thinking that can move the needle, but you need to be bold enough to try." TAPIWA CHIWEWE AI RESEARCHER TED'.

node.text: Ever feel like you're not old enough, not smart enough, or not experienced enough to change the world? Guess what? That’s not true! To solve big problems and make a big impact, you don't have to be an expert says AI researcher Tapiwa Chiwewe. In his TED Talk, he tells the story of discovering the big pollution problem in his city of Johannesburg, South Africa. And even though he knew nothing about environmental science — he knew he had to take action! "Just one fresh perspective, one new skill set, can make the conditions right for something remarkable to happen," he says. Visit the link in our bio to hear about how he developed a platform that tracks pollution trends and helps city planners design for cleaner air. #MondayMotivation

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by TED Talks on July 25, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
How do you create a sacred space for people living in our  busy, distraction-filled world? That was the question driving architect Siamak Hariri when he designed the Bahá’í Temple of South America, and the building that emerged from his imagination is an otherworldly structure filled with light. Made with stone and glass, it appears to be translucent and its unique shape captures the movement of the sun throughout the day. “In a world which is putting up walls, the design needed to express in form the very opposite,” he says. “It had to be open, welcoming to people of all faiths, walks of life, backgrounds, or no faith at all — a new form of sacred space with no pattern or models to draw from.” Hear more about what it takes to design a physical space that speaks volumes on TED Radio Hour. Listen on Apple Podcasts. ⁠
⁠
[Image courtesy of Siamak Hariri]

node.text: What is the real reason that athletes across many sports keep setting new records? Are humans simply getting taller, faster, stronger and just ... better? Or could there be another cause? In his TED Talk, David Epstein (@davidepstein) reveals that there are a number of factors behind the broken records. For one, "a form of artificial selection" has taken place within individual sports, drawing people with very specific body types. Here's an example: After the NBA signed an agreement in 1983 that made basketball a much more lucrative sport, the number of NBA players who were at least 7 feet tall doubled! Watch his fascinating full talk here: http://t.ted.com/kdKa26a
